question: What award was No Worries nominated for?

content.source_1:
Here is a Wikipedia-style entry that presents comprehensive evidence for the statement:

**No Worries (1994 film)**

No Worries is a 1994 Australian film directed by David Elfick. **AACTA Award Nomination**

No Worries was nominated for the AACTA Award for Best Cinematography in 1994. **Evidence**

According to the Australian Academy of Cinema and Television Arts (AACTA) website, No Worries was nominated for Best Cinematography at the 1994 AACTA Awards. [1] This is further supported by a news article published in The Sydney Morning Herald on November 24, 1994, which lists No Worries as one of the nominees for Best Cinematography. [2]

Additionally, the Internet Movie Database (IMDb) also lists No Worries as a nominee for Best Cinematography at the 1994 AACTA Awards. [3]

**References**

[1] Australian Academy of Cinema and Television Arts. (1994). 1994 AACTA Awards Nominees. Retrieved from <https:\/\/www.aacta.org\/awards\/nominees\/1994\/>

[2] The Sydney Morning Herald. (1994, November 24). AACTA Awards Nominees Announced. Retrieved from <https:\/\/www.smh.com.au\/entertainment\/movies\/aacta-awards-nominees-announced-19941124-12q6v.html>

[3] Internet Movie Database. (n.d.). No Worries (1994).
content.source_2:
**HEADLINE:** Aussie Short Film "No Worries" Makes Waves at Oscars with Nomination for Best Live Action Short Film

**LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 1995**

In a major coup for Australian cinema, David Elfick's poignant short film "No Worries" has been nominated for the prestigious Academy Award for Best Live Action Short Film. The announcement was made yesterday at the Samuel Goldwyn Theater in Beverly Hills, sending shockwaves of excitement through the film community. "No Worries," which premiered at the Sydney Film Festival in 1994, tells the heartwarming story of a young boy's journey to overcome his fears and find solace in the Australian outback. The 23-minute film has been praised for its stunning cinematography, nuanced performances, and Elfick's sensitive direction. "I'm completely overwhelmed," Elfick said in an exclusive interview with our publication. "To be recognized by the Academy is a dream come true. It's a testament to the hard work and dedication of our entire cast and crew." The film's nomination is seen as a major milestone for Australian cinema, which has been gaining momentum in recent years. "No Worries" is the first Australian short film to be nominated for an Oscar since 1986. "This is a fantastic achievement for David and his team," said Australian Film Commission CEO, Kim Dalton. "It's a proud moment for our industry, and we're thrilled to see our talent being recognized on the global stage." According to data from the Australian Film Institute, "No Worries" has been screened at over 20 film festivals worldwide, garnering critical acclaim and numerous awards. The film's success has also sparked interest from distributors, with several major studios reportedly vying for the rights to release the film theatrically. Elfick, who is currently in Los Angeles preparing for the Oscars ceremony, expressed his gratitude to the Academy and his team. "I'm so grateful to have had the opportunity to share this story with the world. I'm looking forward to celebrating with my fellow nominees and enjoying this incredible honor." The 67th Academy Awards will take place on March 25, 1995, at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. "No Worries" will compete against four other short films from around the world for the coveted Best Live Action Short Film award.
